headline: Authentic Cincinnati Chili
description: Cincinnati chili is Ohio-style comfort food! This recipe will feed a crowd; serve over hot spaghetti or have it 4-Way with onions and Cheddar cheese.
name: Authentic Cincinnati Chili
recipeIngredient: 1 quart water, or amount to cover

recipeInstructions.text: Place ground beef in a large pan, cover with cold water, and bring to a boil, stirring and breaking up beef with a fork to a fine texture. Slowly boil until meat is thoroughly cooked, about 30 minutes.

Add onions, tomato sauce, vinegar, garlic, Worcestershire sauce, and chocolate. Stir in chili powder, salt, cumin, cinnamon, and cayenne pepper until well mixed. Add cloves, allspice berries, and bay leaf.
Bring to a boil, reduce heat to a simmer, and cook, stirring occasionally, for 3 hours. Add water if necessary to prevent chili from burning.

review.reviewBody: We love this recipe. We did add one green pepper, small diced and substituted ground chicken instead of beef. The flavors of all the spice come together for a wonderful aromatic and tasty treat. We have served it over spaghetti squash, great low carb option.
Very good. I haven't had this since I lost a recipe for Skyline Chili I got from a friend from Cincinnati years ago. The ingredients are similar or maybe the same, from what I remember.
I add 1/2 tsp of cloves and 1/2 teaspoon of allspice. As well as some Cayenne

I tried this recipe and it was very good. I modified it a little, I added a can of Kidney Beans, an ounce of Bakers chocolate, I served it on top of spaghetti and topped it with cheese, onions and sour cream. Delicious!
This chili is super flavorful, if not just a tad too spicy. I think I'll stick to my chili sans pasta.

When making this. 3 notes Use apple cider vinegar not white And if you don't have 2 days to dedicate to this dish, use the leanest ground beef. I use 97/3...way less fat if any . No need to refrigerate and skim the next day. I used 3 ounces of tomatoe paste vs the sauce
Excellent although a little spicy for my mother but my husband and I will definitely do again

This was great - made it for the Super Bowl when the Bengals were playing. A big hit with everyone. Definitely different from other chilis I've had/made, but in a good way. Served with spaghetti, raw onion, and cheddar. Would try beans, as well, next time!
Pretty darn good and authentic. Too bad the game didn't go the Bengals way!!

Made this for the Super Bowl. The chili was an absolute winner. My only suggestion is to moderate the addition of cayenne pepper depending on the chili powder you choose. . If using a spicy chili powder, additional cayenne may not be necessary.

This was a very strange chilie recipe considering where I live (New Mexico). I am originally from Ohio and wanting to make something more Ohio-ish for the Super Bowl I thought I would feature a Skyline Chilie aka: Cincinnati chilie bar to honor the Bengals. I boiled the meat in low sodium Beef bone broth and removed 98% of the fat. I used about 1/2 tsp. ground allspice and cloves because who wants to bite into an whole clove or allspice berry? Not me! I then put it in the Slow Cooker for 3 hours. When it looked a little dry, I threw in some beer. OMG I think I now have a third style of chili to add to my lineup! It was delicious on spaghetti, hot dogs and the NM staple; Frito Pie! Thank you for sharing this recipe!
reduced the onion - some family prefers less of these ingredients. YUM!
This is my first time making Chili and I'm glad my family enjoyed it! Thank you for sharing this recipe!
This recipe is fantastic. It's earthy, spicy, and savory all at the same time. I only made one change and that was to use homemade beef stock instead of water.

Most disappointing. It was supposed to be the star of Halloween night. I followed recipes to the T. The only flavor was pure cloves. Thank goodness. Swedish meatballs. And German sausage saved the night. I can't believe this dish ever became note worthy.

Firstly, I’ve never been to Cincinnati so don’t really have anyway to compare. That being said I really enjoyed and will definitely make again. My teenage daughter and wife not so much though. I did try making from another recipe years ago and didn’t really like that one.

A few suggestions: use 1 teaspoon of ground allspice in place of allspice berries as suggested by others. Also, you MUST get a block of cheddar and grate your own cheese. None of that dry, flour coated in the bags. It makes a HUGE difference. The next time I make this I plan to run the cooked beef and water through a food processor. You want it as fine as possible.

We are a chili family and I have made near a dozen of different chilies. This is one of several no bean chilis that I have made and the family just loved. The flavor was amazing and the kids all gave it 5 stars. The only trouble I had was that I doubled the recipe and seemed to end up with too much liquid. The result was that it took me a bit longer to cook it down. Never had Cincinnati chili before but it is on the remake list at our house.

I have made this at least 10 times! This winter I started sub-ing 1 pound of the lean ground beef with Impossible Beef (made of vegetables) and you can’t even tell the difference. We have it two ways: on tortilla chips with melted cheese (nachos for my husband) and on macaroni with cheese, kidney beans, sour cream and green onions. Delicious both ways! BTW, I sub half of ground beef with the Impossible Beef in other recipes like spaghetti sauce an no one can tell...and my cholesterol level has gone down!
Canned the chili based on instructions from Ball’s chili recipe and canning info.

This was my first time making this recipe and it was fabulous. My family and friends loved it and everybody went back for seconds. The only change I made was replacing the allspice berries and clove berries with 1 teaspoon each since I did not have berries on hand. This is definitely a keeper.

Made this per recipe—very authentic to my memory of when we lived in Ohio. The 3 hour simmer is the key. Tasted before the simmer and then again after—VERY DIFFERENT. This s a Skyline chili keeper recipe for me!

Oh. My. Goodness. This is so good, I'm sitting here eating a small bowl at 10:20 at night before putting it in the fridge for tomorrow. SO. GOOD.

I did add dark red kidney beans and diced tomatoes, but otherwise followed the recipe.

SO GOOD
Makes me long for winter. My favorite cold weather food.

Holy cow! I’ve never eaten Cincinnati chili. I made it for my boyfriend who’s from Wisconsin. How did I live without this?! It’s fantastic! I made it just like it said but I used ground spices instead of the berries. This will be a permanent fixture in my recipe box now. Thanks!

Made as the recipe stated.

Added some sneaky beans to the chili. (can of organic black refried beans) 

Didn't add the vinegar, but I bet it would have been fine. Honesty even apple cider vinegar. Probably would add next time for myself.
Don't skip the step of overnight refrigeration, it makes a big difference.
family loves it
Authentic. Makes me feel like I’m in Cinci!
Spot on Cincinnati Chili...I lived there for 19 years and was missing the taste...made this leaving out the hot pepper and it was fantabulous!!!
It is really authentic! The color may throw you off but the flavor is just like Skyline!! Loved it!
I have to agree with some of the 2 and 3 star ratings, not what I expected.

Used ground cloves (1/4 tsp), ground allspice (1/4 tsp), garlic powder (2t), and cocoa powder (2T). Didn't have tomato sauce, so blended canned tomato in the food processor and added tomato paste. Served over spaghetti with cheddar cheese. Yummy!
Thanks for posting this recipe,it was very good. I love Cincinnati, Gold Star and Empress chilis. I could never stand the ground beef, always upset my stomach. I used quinoa instead and it works.

My sister in Law bulked at me when she heard that I brought Cincinnati chili to our family function. She grew up on Skyline Chili and says that she's never found another place that serves authentic Cincinnati chili. But once she tried this recipe she actually said: " This is pretty close". I consider that high praise.
Wonderful! Even better than Skyline!

We loved this! I've made it twice so far. I used a 1/2 tsp ground cloves, 1/2 tsp allspice, and 2 Tbl cocoa powder. I boiled the ground beef in the morning then refrigerated it about 4 hrs then scraped the grease off the top. Although I love the idea of getting rid of the grease, I think I should leave a little on for flavor and to stick to the spaghetti better. It makes the house smell great as it cooks. The onions shouldn't be added in as you cook it. They should be served raw on top.
This is the real deal! We need very low sodium for health reasons - without the salt,you need to cut back on the cinnamon (by about half), but otherwise, it works! Yay!

This is a great recipe. Delicious!!

This is the only recipe for Chile that my husband likes. We make it to use as Hotdog Sauce. This is so good. 

What you buy in the grocery store is usually made with soy and there is not really any meat in them.

Try this you will love it, There are only 2 of us, so I either cut it in half or make it all and freeze it n smaller containers.

I had doubts but it was a close to the real thing as I can get. Not exact but just as good in its own right. Love those aromatic flavors. I don't really eat pasta anymore but this turned out so good I'm using it in a 4 way tomorrow! To heck with low carb for one day lol. Thanks for sharing this treasure. I didn't have Worcester sauce so I used a steak sauce I got in Mexico when on vacation. Also I did thicken it slightly during the last 20 minutes of simmer by adding just a touch of masa mixed in warm water.

I tried Cincinnati Chili years ago. I used this recipe and it brought back the wonderful aromas and intricate balances of seasonings for the best chili! I'm making it for a chili cook-off at our local church. It will be a crowd pleaser.

Everyone has said it all. We loved this filling and warming meal. We added the 5 WAY options, Cheese, Pasta, Kidney Beans and Onions. OH MY MY!! The only thing I would let everyone know is that this feeds 4-5 people with one good serving two each with smaller servings.

I skipped the first step, and went for it with fat included (did use extra lean). It was dead on, loved it. Grew up in the Cincy area ( live out West now) and had tried to replicate the recipe many times over the years and came close. All the onion was what I was missing. Thanks a million for the recipe it’s perfect.

This is the only Cincy chili recipe that cooks the beef properly. It is to be cooked in simmering water and broken apart into fine pieces of beef. The meat should never be browned. To simplify the recipe, I add extra water in the beginning break apart the meat, then add everything else. I use very lean meat so there is very little fat. The I simmer for at least

This was very authentic. We used ground Allspice and Ground Clove in the recipe. We needed to short-cut the time so we drained the beef in a fine colander and cooked the chili for about 2 1/2 hours. Served on an oval plate spaghetti/Chili/Onion/Beans/Cheese and about half a bottle of crystal added as we worked our way across the plate section by section so you got all 5 ingredients in every bite.

Wanting Cincinnati chili similar to one a regional chain in MD and VA (!) serves, this recipe seemed the best. Hint: after adding water to the beef in the pan, an old fashioned “squiggly” potato masher makes the beef VERY finely chopped very quickly.

Two small changes for next time: 1) The clove flavor was a bit too strong, although I folllowed the ground clove to whole clove equivalent and even subtracted a bit. 1/8 tsp. should equal about one clove, and I multiplied by 4 instead of 5. Still too much. And 2) no need to keep the ground beef in the frig overnight - just until any fat rises to the top, which is then very easy to “peel” off with a spoon or spatula. All in all a really nice dish. Will make it a bunch. Oh - and I added about 1.5 tsps of brown sugar like some others.

I've made this about 20 times...looked for years for a recipe similar to the Cincinnati chili at Hard Times Cafe in Alexandria, Virginia and this one is spot on! LOVE IT!! 

To folks giving this bad reviews because it doesn't taste like 'regular/normal chili' - it's NOT supposed to. Cincinnati / Skyline Chili has a unique and different flavor and no, it's not for everyone. But please don't give this a bad review because it's not like 'regular/normal' chili! That's like making a Chicken Noodle Soup recipe and saying it was bad because it didn't taste like Chicken Curry Soup!! Just sayin'! ;)
I’m from Cleveland, but I love this Cincinnati chili!
I didn't use cajun spice. Too spicy for my family.

Don't live in Ohio and have never had Cincinnati chili. Having said that, , this stuff is GOOD! After I boiled the ground beef, I used my immersion blender to obtain the fine consistency. Followed the recipe exactly, but didn't have whole allspice or cloves so use ground instead. Piled on top of spaghetti, with raw chopped onions and a huge pile of very finely shredded cheddar cheese, this is my idea of heaven on a plate. I could eat it for breakfast, lunch and dinner! Thanks so much for sharing. Now I don't have to go to Cincy, so it's a win-win.

This is now winter-time comfort food at our house. I'm from Texas, and thought my husband had lost his mind years ago when he came home with a can of skyline chili from a business trip. Well, I liked it enough to search for a recipe and make it at home. I still like my Texas chili, too, don't get me wrong. But sometimes my tummy can't handle the hot spices of a good ole bowl of Texas chili and just wants warm and comfy chili. Like this. We love it!

We are all big fans of Cincinnati Chili (which is not often served at restaurants here in Washington DC), so I made this one. It was delicious and very easy (as long as you remember you need to start the evening before to let the meat chill in the refrigerator overnight.) I may try a bit more chocolate and cinnamon next time as the sweet/spiciness ratio was a bit more on the spicy side and I'm curious what upping those two ingredients would taste like. Great recipe!
Very good for chili cheese tots, Dogs etc. I didn't bother with cooking it and letting it sit over night, then skim, to get that pure true drive in chili sauce feel.
Mom used to make it when we were kids, Bring me back.

Spot on! I spent the first decade of my life in Cincinnati, still have family there. I use to have my parents send me spice packets to make Cincinnati chili but decided to take it on myself. This recipe nails it. I have made a few modifications though. I use 90/10 ground beef and skip the skimming. I feel that cooking the meat with the spices helps steep in the flavor. I only use one large onion finely chopped, don't skimp on the garlic, and add a little additional salt. I have also found that tomato paste give a better flavor profile than sauce.

We live right on the Ohio border, and used to drive into Eaton just to get out Skyline fix. We finally got one in town, and it went out of business! I was reduced to buying cans or frozen (expensive and not as good!) Until I found this. I've tried other versions, and honestly this comes closest. 
 This recipe is so close that I make a double batch, and freeze half. The kids can heat some up for Coney's whenever they want, and I can get my 4-way fix.
I do, after skimming the fat, use my immersion blender to get that extra fine texture. That texture really does make a big difference in the final product.

This recipe was delicious and was exactly what I was looking for. It was also easy to make. I froze half so I could have easy dinners and lunches for some time. Think the kids are going to love it. I am a Cincinnati native who has been gone for many many years, and have experimented with many different recipes. I will say that I wasn't expecting much when I boiled the meat as the first step. The approach was much different from other types of cooking I've done. But it worked and was very accurate.

I made the following adjustments:
Did not skim the fat or let it congeal overnight. 
1 lb ground beef. 1 lb ground lamb.
Forgot the bay leaf.
After initial boil, transferred to a slow cooker and let simmer for 12 hours, then put in fridge overnight to consume the next day. 

This recipe is LEGIT. Yum!
Family loved it. I didn't change a thing.

This is one of those "I signed up for AllRecipes just to review this one" kind of story. I browse this site frequently, though truth be told I'm not a devoted follower of any one recipe site. Still, I find myself here frequently, and it's time I shared my gratitude.

First of all, I do not claim to be from Cincinnati, nor even the area, so I can't say how 'authentic' this is. I will say I've eaten at Skyline about every time I've been through that town, and I don't know that I would call this their actual recipe (regardless of whatever had previously been printed).

Still, my experience with Cincy style chilis definitely puts this one up there as a regional recipe, there is no doubt. And my modifications did not hurt the overall final product.

I did not see the part about starting it the day before, so that was problem one. Solution? Simple. Brown the meat without the water, drain the fat off, then go right into the onion saute. BE SURE TO ADD MORE WATER LATER, THOUGH. Since I don't know how much of the original quart of H2O remains after a three hour simmer and chilling overnight, I started with half that amount. I think I added another cup later, so three cups total, but please don't quote me on that. Besides, the nice part about this method is, you get to decide how tight or loose you want the chili to be.

Otherwise, I used the ingredients and method down to the T, and it was amazing. I would definitely make this again!

I ALWAYS stop for Cincinnati Skyline Chili whenever passing through. If I don't I hear about it for some time afterward. Our entire family loves it, and I get orders by text when they know I'm near Cincinnati. It is an acquired taste, I think.
This recipe comes so close to the original, but isn't quite there. I've been playing around with the ingredients but find this is still better.
I rarely refrigerate the meat overnight. I find that a few hours is just fine for me to skim the fat. Also, DON'T BROWN THE MEAT or you will not get that Skyline type chili. 
Thanks so much!
This is THE chili. I lived in Cincy long ago. Then one day a few years ago I woke up with the urge to eat this chili. And this recipe makes the same chili you get at Skyline. It’s incredible.

Tastes like the Skyline Chili I grew up with!

I highly recommend that after cooking, you let the finished chili sit in the fridge at least a day.

Tastes dead on with Skyline! if people don't like it they don't like it, but this is the recipe if you're looking for the Skyline taste. 

 Two recommendations -separate the liquid from the ground beef before you put in in the fridge. Makes it easier to separate. Also be sure to pull out the cloves and allspice berries and bay leaf before serving. 

I found that one lb of spaghetti wasn't enough for this recipe. make two pounds or cut the recipe in half. And a little bit of beans goes a long way. One or two cans drained and rinsed would be plenty or abt a 1/4 bag of dry beans.

I'm not sure what the point is in skimming the fat. You lose a lot of flavor that way, and there's no health benefit to it (see a plethora of recent research on the lack of a real link between dietary fat and cholesterol and heart disease). 

It needs a bit more of...something. The flavor balance is right, so I think possibly adding half again as much of every flavoring agent, from the spices to the vinegar, would do it.
If you’re looking for legit Cincinnati Chili taste, this is it. Worth the time.

We recently returned from Cincinnati where we ate at Skyline Chili. We loved their chili so I decided to try and duplicate it here in Texas. This recipie was a tad spicier than what we experienced in Ohio. It was really good. I will make this again for my family.

This is awesome!
I tried Skyline Chili about 20 years ago when they briefly opened a few restaurants in Florida. I was hooked after a few visits, but they promptly closed.
I have since been able to buy the canned chili, but the fat content makes it only possible to enjoy on a rare occasion.
I've tried a couple other recipes, and while close, they just weren't right.
This recipe is perfect! The only difference I made was boiling the beef, and then rinsing it in a colander lined with cheesecloth to eliminate the fat. After that, I threw it into the electric pressure cooker, and put in on the soup function with the remaining ingredients exactly.
Perfection!

The original 1946 recipe for Skyline, not Cincinnati chili, has no chili powder included. You can do about whatever you want ,within reason , to Cincy Chili as hometown folks have got their own best method. To enhance the flavor of your Skyline, be sure to boil the ground beef and chill overnight. It makes a difference. For those of you who wanted to know where the beans and veggies were in this chili, you have come to the wrong chili site. Now if someone from Cincy can give me a Goetta recipe, I would be ever grateful.I lost my great grandmother's recipes cards. ( it took 3 cards to get it all down)

My husband grew up in Ohio and has fond memories of skyline chili growing up and I wanted to prepare one of his childhood favorites. I fully admit that my palette is not developed towards "midwestern cuisine" but this is just not good. Smells okay but minimal bland flavor, no vegetables, zero texture. Requires a stiff shot of tapatio to get it down.

I was making this when I realized there are no beans in it. I'm not familiar with Cincinnati chili so maybe I'm not the right critic for this recipe. I've added white beans and kidney beans to make it more familiar to me. It's cooking at present and I'm sure it will be good, with the beans.

Within 24 hours we had Skyline Chili at their restaurant and the next day we decided to try this recipe..

THIS IS THE BEST!!!! 
CHANGES....Only used 1 1/2# ground beef and it was quite lean so we went straight ahead with the recipe. No waiting overnight. Our OHIO family members agreed.

Very good. Had Skyline chili many times in Cincinnati when in college. Almost perfect ... maybe a little sweeter. But delicious and pretty close. Great on hot dogs and spaghetti with cheese and onions!!!

Full disclosure: I'm not from Cincinnati, have never been to Cincinnati, nor have I ever had Skyline Chili. However, a diner in Upstate NY offers this dish and it's delicious so I sought out a recipe, ultimately choosing this one. I measured everything to spec with the exception of whole cloves or allspice berries, which I didn't have. I have ground. Several people in the reviews have stated that 1 tsp ground = 5 whole cloves/ berries and that's the measurement I went with. BIG MISTAKE. The clove-taste dominated this dish. Cinnamon? Cayenne? Salt? Could barely taste 'em; it was all cloves, all the time. Despite that, the outcome was still pretty good. My suggestions for improvements: ease up on the clove use when using ground. If you don't have whole cloves, use 1/2 - 3/4 tsp ground. Also, do NOT use 93% ground beef for this as I did. This chili needs some of that delicious fat, so go 85% or lower. This recipe got me on the right track for what I'm looking for so, for that, thank you.

It was really good. I didn't skim the fat; I was more concerned with flavor than healthiness. I was also able to make it in one setting by skipping that process. The flavor was great, but after cooking so long it lost some of its taste. I (liberally) added salt and allspice at the 2 hour mark and stopped cooking at 2 1/2 hours. I'm going to experiment with cooking times in the future, but all in all it was a great bowl of Cincinnati chili more comparable to Empress than Goldstar or Skyline in my opinion. Living in San Diego it was nice to be able to make it without relying on the family to send me packets, and the taste was slightly superior to the packets in my opinion.

I followed this recipe exactly and it was just like being home again. The store-bought shredded cheese wouldn't do this recipe justice. For the most authentic experience, I set out bowls of oyster crackers and a bottle of hot sauce. We boiled some hot dogs and steamed the buns to add to the experience. 

I make the trip to Cincinnati about once a year and a trip to Skyline or Gold Star is one indulgence that I always look forward and toward. This recipe just brought me a little closer to home.
Made it for my Texan fiancé, he went back for seconds and told me it was REALLY good. I like it with extra cocoa in it. He likes it with powdered ghost pepper in it.

I made 1/2 the recipe and this was some amazing stuff!! I will make a whole batch next time so I can freeze for later. I used Cocoa powder, ground allspice, ground cloves, and ground bay leaf because that was what I had on hand and it turned out wonderful. So good!! Very glad I found this! Thank you!
Awesome! Just like Skyline chili.
Easy to make and deliciously authentic tasting. Spooned over angel hair pasta and topped with shredded cheddar. An unforgettable flavor!

Love this recipe. Remember the beef will look gross until it all comes together.

Changes: 2 TB chili powder, 1/2 teaspoon ground coves, skipped allspice( suggested 1 tsp ground) and bay leaves (2)
By itself, this is a little saltier than I prefer, but I didn't have a problem with that when eating on top of spaghetti. My husband was very pleased with this and wants me to make it again!

Excellent, to the ingredient base I add 4-5 whole cardamon seeds, tomato paste instead of sauce, cocoa, 8oz of V-8 juice, and double down on the cinnamon, cloves, allspice, and Worcestershire sauce and then a final spin with handheld blender to refine the consistency of the ingredients.

This is the Crack of chili recipes! If you don't like Skyline you won't like it - it's something people love or hate. But if you love Skyline this is for you! I used half turkey and half beef because that's what I had. Served it over spaghetti squash (for wheat free - if you are not serving this over some type of spaghetti you are doing it wrong) with grated cheddar and sour cream - heaven!!

I've made it three times. It's like skyline. Perfect. BUT, hold salt until the very end of cooking. The chili powder you use may have salt; Worcestershire has salt; tomato sauce also could have of salt. Add that to the 1 1/2 tsp salt of the recipe and you could have an insane amount of salt. With the ingredients I use, I find that only 1/2 tsp is about right. I recommend you add salt and find the amount you like.
I admittedly have not had the authentic Skyline Chili in Cincinnati, but I made this tonight and it was delicious! I think this will also be a great meat sauce to add to chili fries, nachos, etc.

Unlike one reviewer stated, this isn't Skyline's recipe, how could it be? That's a closely guarded secret. But it's close. I used to make this recipe for years when I lived overseas, Jonesing for Skyline. The one big difference I would make here is that you have to break up the ground beef with your hands in cold water BEFORE boiling with spices. That's how you get a really fine texture that Skyline has. And I use more cumin. Also, no point in using lower fat ground beef if you're going to skim. But my Greek father-in-law would never skim anyway. Here's a link to the recipe postcard I used...
http://1.bp.blogspot.com/_Ous-nx-eKis/SBNT7bCKX7I/AAAAAAAAAGI/y5Md7Ld_YLs/s1600/postcard+cinci.jpg
I add a little BBQ sauce but this recipe is great as is!!
Only had ground all spice, but the other reviews helped. Great

Made this VEGETARIAN style. Instead of ground beef, used 1 bag of Morningstar Farms or Boca Burger crumbles (12 ounces). Put in enough water to cover the crumbles and let simmer for 15-20 minutes while the remainder of spices were prepared and used half of the spice recommendation since I was only using 12 ounces of crumbles. Use entire spice recommendation if using 2 bags of crumbles. I then let the mixture simmer for 30-40 minutes which boiled off a little bit of the water and made a nice chili texture. Let sit in refrigerator overnight for spices to absorb and served that following evening. Even the non vegetarians loved the VEGETARIAN version. Halving it made 6 filling dishes. If you want to make the VEGAN version of this, leave out the worcheshire sauce (contains anchovies), use diaya vegan cheese, and make sure your pasta is vegan.

I have tried for years to find out exactly what Skyline chili was putting in their delicious chili, and this poster has hit the nail on the head! Don't leave anything out that op lists. Thanks so much for solving this mystery for me :)

The only thing I changed was one technique. Because Skyline is so finely ground, (the beef) I chose to cook it, then pulse a few times in food processor before returning to pot. I did the same with the onion before cooking.
Because I grind my own lean meat instead of using ground beef, I was able to skip the skimming off fat step.
Fantastic.

Great dish. An excellent alternative to plain chili or plain spaghetti. I chose to colander the meat after it was cooked and rinsed it with the spray nozel. This got rid of the fat and ground it up better. Then right into the crock pot it went. Done in less than 4 hours. :)
Family Favorite...try a little extra chocolate and cinnamon!!

Wonderful recipe...I used a teaspoon each of ground allspice and ground cloves because that's what I had on hand. I also thought it was done after simmering just an hour; three would have been too much. This is delicious and I look forward to making it often.

Made it all in a day and although probably better over two days, it still tasted great! One comment was to add water while simmering but we careful not to add too much because it makes the chili runny. Over angel hair or a coney, this definitely tastes like the real thing!
So good. Very easy to make. Family loves it too!

After 2 years in California and 3 years in New Mexico, I've become a bit of a chili fanatic. This is my first taste of Cincinnati chili and while it's very different from, say, carne adovada, I'm now a fan! I used ground NM red chile instead of chili powder, ground allspice instead of the berries and half a Mexican hot chocolate disk instead of the unsweetened (all due to the contents of my cupboard). Served over spaghetti with a touch of sharp white cheddar and some onion. Next time I'll make sure I have mild orange and oyster crackers on hand so I can do it up right. Here's to chili in all its incarnations!

I loved this recipe! The only thing I did differently was I didn't cook the meat and refrigerate overnight. Instead I drained the fat after cooking the meet. I also didn't add water to the meat when cooking it. Instead I had about a quart to all the ingredients once I cooked the meet and transferred over to a bigger pot. Also make sure you keep stirring the chili because otherwise it will burn quick because of the chocolate in it.

I went the uber-lazy route and put all ingredients, plus 1 quart of water, in the crockpot, and cooked it on low for about 8 hours. I also used ground turkey instead of ground beef. The flavor is good; however, not boiling off the water made the end result a bit watery. No doubt, it'll be better if I simmer it, uncovered, on the stove for a bit to get rid of that excess water. Otherwise, I'd say its a solid recipe, and this is coming from someone who has been to Skyline Chili MANY times.
